name: What the Bleep Is Going On? Quiz | Common Bond 10 Questions | 10 Questions

questions.text: The doctor just told me I am going to be in the hospital for quite awhile as a quiz coma is a very serious thing. He tells me to try to figure out what year it is; that such activity will be good for my brain. So I settle back, turn on the TV and see which man being sworn in as the 37th President of the United States?
questions.explanation:
Richard Nixon.

	On January 20th Richard Nixon was sworn in as the 37th President of the United States. He was forced to resign during his second term in office due to the Watergate scandal.

questions.text: It's now February 8th and the nurse brings me the final monthly issue of which American magazine known for its wonderful covers?
questions.explanation:
The Saturday Evening Post.

	The first issue of "The Saturday Evening Post" was published in 1897. Famed American artist Norman Rockwell had over 300 of his paintings grace the cover of this iconic magazine.

questions.text: There is only so much I can do while lying in a hospital bed, and so the TV is back on. I have just learned that which person became the first female Prime Minister of Israel?
questions.explanation:
Golda Meir.

	Long before Margaret Thatcher was known as the "Iron Lady" in the male dominated world of politics, Golda Meir held this moniker. Born in Russia and raised in the United States, Meir was a strong, intelligent woman who did her very best to lead a country embroiled in turmoil.

questions.text: I have been lying here for what seems like forever. The nurses are buzzing all around, talking about the first X-rated movie to win an Academy Award. What is the name of this John Schlesinger film that they are all talking about?
questions.explanation:
Midnight Cowboy.

	Starring Dustin Hoffman and Jon Voight, "Midnight Cowboy" became the first X-rated movie to win an Academy Award for Best Picture. Although this movie was extremely controversial because of sexual content, including homosexuality, in 1994 the film was selected for preservation in the United States National Film Registry because of its cultural significance.

questions.text: The calendar on the wall says that it is now July 18th. I still have not been able to figure out what year it is. Now the TV is reporting that a famous man was in a motor vehicle accident at a location called Chappaquiddick Island and that a female in the car died. I am still having problems remembering things; can you tell me in which American state Chappaquiddick Island is located?
questions.explanation:
Massachusetts.

	Chappaquiddick Island is located at the eastern end of the upscale area known as Martha's Vineyard, in the lovely state of Massachusetts. The island was largely unknown outside of Martha's Vineyard until then-Senator Edward Kennedy had a motor vehicle accident that killed his passenger Mary Jo Kopechne. Kennedy  managed to escape from the car, which he had driven off a bridge into the water. Any presidential aspirations by him or his political party came to an end when it was learned he did not report the accident.

questions.text: The calendar says it's July 20th and I am still here in the bed trying to remember what year it is. I look at the TV and now I see a man in a funny white suit with a white bubble-shaped helmet. He is talking about a giant leap for mankind and has planted an American flag in some desolate looking ground. What remarkable place is this man visiting?
questions.explanation:
The Moon.

	People around the world were riveted to their television screens when Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin became the first two humans to land on the moon. They collected 49 lbs. (22 kilograms) of moon rocks before leaving. They made it safely back to Earth along with the third member of the crew, Michael Collins, who flew into space twice, but never got his chance to step on the moon.

questions.text: It's mid-August and I still cannot figure out what year it is. An outdoor music festival called Woodstock has made the news. In which American state did this occur?
questions.explanation:
New York.

	The Woodstock music festival was held on a dairy farm in Bethel, New York. This legendary outdoor concert and party included such performers as The Who, Creedence Clearwater Revival and Jimi Hendrix. Despite bad weather and negative media coverage, those who attended this event in a soggy cow pasture consider themselves to be lucky folks indeed.

questions.text: I am still struggling to figure out what year it is--and when I am getting out of this hospital. Quiz coma is a terrible affliction. My mood is slightly uplifted by watching which new television show about a blended family with six children and a maid named Alice.
questions.explanation:
The Brady Bunch & brady bunch.

	"The Brady Bunch" was an American sit-com that was watched by generations of Americans, both when it was on prime-time television and after it was nationally syndicated. It lasted five seasons and was one of the first shows to center around a blended family that included remarriage and learning how to make two separate families into one, as part of the plot.

questions.text: It is December now, and I read in the papers that Princess Alice of Battenberg passed away. The article mentions her son Phillip and his wife who is the Queen of which European nation?
questions.explanation:
The United Kingdom.

	Princess Alice of Battenberg was the wife of Prince Andrew of Greece and Denmark. She was the mother-in-law of Queen Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom. This remarkable woman, who had a congenital hearing defect, nevertheless spoke four languages fluently. She was considered a hero by many when it became known she had sheltered persecuted Jews during World War II.

questions.text: Finally, the doctor says I can be released. I realized that the four numbers following a month and a day indicated the year. That was all I had needed to do, but a quiz coma really messes up your thought process.  Using the previous questions as hints, can you figure out what year my quiz coma rehab occurred?
questions.explanation:
1969.

	All of the things in questions one through nine occurred in 1969. In spite of my amnesia, I can remember it was a year of change and upheaval. Just a prelude of the upcoming 70s. 1) Richard Nixon became President of the US in 1969.2) "The Saturday Evening Post" saw its final issue in 1969.3) Golda Meir became the first female Prime Minister of Israel in 1969.4) "Midnight Cowboy" became the first X-rated movie to win an Academy Award for Best Picture in 1969.5) Edward Kennedy was in a motor vehicle accident at Chappaquiddick Island in 1969.6) Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin became the first two humans to land on the moon in 1969.7) The Woodstock music festival was held in Bethel, New York in 1969.8) "The Brady Bunch" was an American sit-com that first aired in 1969.9) Princess Alice of Battenberg died in December 1969.
